revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Use British English|date=September 2012}} {{BLP sources|date=June 2007}}
[[File:Phil Kay Goodfather Comedy.jpg|thumb|right|Kay in 2013]] '''Phil Kay''' (born 1969) is a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[Stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]].
==Biography==
===Education=== Kay was educated at [[Craigclowan Preparatory School]] in [[Perth, Scotland]] and at nearby [[Glenalmond College]].<ref name="craigclowan">{{cite book |editor1-last=Hay |editor1-first=Erika |title=Craigclowan: The First 50 Years 1952-2002 |publisher=Craigclowan Preparatory School |year=2002}}</ref>{{rp|33}}<ref name="glenalmond">{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12437013.THE_BEST_DAYS_OF_YOUR_LIFE__Phil_Kay__comedian/ |title=The best days of your life Phil Kay, Comedian |newspaper=[[The Herald (Glasgow)]] |date=21 February 2006 |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref>
===Early career=== Kay became known to the public when he won the newcomer's competition, '[[So You Think You're Funny]]', at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 1989. He then went on to be nominated for the prestigious Perrier Award in 1993.<ref name="Phil Kay">{{cite web|url=http://www.spoonfed.co.uk/artist/comedy-1524/phil-kay-20232|publisher=Spoonfed.co.uk|title=Phil Kay profile|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref> He won the award for Best Stand-Up at the [[British Comedy Awards]] in 1994.<ref>[http://www.gildedballoon.co.uk/So_You_Think_Youre_Funny/Phil_Kay_1989.htm Profilel]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, gildedballoon.co.uk; accessed 3 October 2015.</ref>
Kay continued to work worldwide as a live stand-up, most notably on regular and very successful tours of the [[Adelaide Festival]] and [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]] in [[Australia]].{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
===Later career=== Following his rise to comedic fame, Phil has also gone on to other adventures such as selling books in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]]. In April 2012, his show at Aberdeen's Blue Lamp was cut short. He was later rebooked, making a virtue of Kay’s notoriety, billing the gig as The Meltdown Part II and actively encouraging punters to stay away. This time, the venue, Snafu, was a lot happier, posting on Facebook afterwards: ‘Phil Kay... what can I say. Absolutely stormed it at Breakneck Comedy tonight!’ <ref>[http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2012/10/19/16349/what_we_promote_is_a_mr_bean_lifestyle Profile], chortle.co.uk, 19 October 2012; accessed 3 October 2015.</ref> In August 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015 he performed sold out runs at the Edinburgh Fringe performing on Bob Slayer's Heroes of Fringe.
==Television work== Kay hosted his own stand-up comedy series on [[Channel 4]] in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] called ''Phil Kay Feels...'', recorded in front of a live audience in 1997. His other works on television have included ''Next Stop, Phil Kay'' (also on Channel 4), ''Edinburgh Nights'' ([[BBC1]]) and ''The Montreal Festival of Fun'' ([[Five (channel)|Channel 5]]). In conjunction with filmmaker Archie Lauchlan, he also released ''That Phil Kay Video'' onto the retail market in 2000. This unique collection of Kay's live standup gigs was re-released in 2014 via Video On Demand (see [https://vimeo.com/ondemand/thatphilkayvideo vimeo.com/ondemand/thatphilkayvideo here]).
He has remained largely behind-the-scenes on television to date, with writing credits including [[Jonathan Ross (television presenter)|Jonathan Ross]]'s ''Saturday Show'', [[Channel 4]]'s ''[[Viva Cabaret]]'', ''[[The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer]]'', ''[[Sean's Show]]'', [[Harry Hill]]'s ''Pilot Show'', and many more.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} He has appeared as a panellist on the BBC television show ''[[QI]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://qi.com/episode-b10-bills|title=QI : Quite Interesting|website=qi.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-13}}</ref> On 19 November 2009, he appeared as the stand-up act on the [[BBC Three]] television show ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/russell_howards_good_news/episodes/1/5/|title=Russell Howard's Good News Series 1, Episode 5 - British Comedy Guide|last=Guide|first=British Comedy|website=British Comedy Guide|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-06-13}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.philkay.co.uk official website]
